comment_text:
IMPOTANT NOTE1: I have revised my opinion about what it smells like. In the video, I said it was like an indoor pool and I correlated it to the chlorine. However, I think it's more accurate to say the pool locker room or shower. It is musty/moldy, with a background of pool smell.

IMPORTANT NOTE2: After posting this video, I got a few messages from people saying that in their experience, cyanide DOES smell like almonds. So, I spent an hour tonight doing some tests, and I think the results are interesting. I did some direct comparisons and the smell of cyanide is distinctly different from the smell of almonds. However, if I EAT the almonds, there is sometimes a faint taste of cyanide. I think this is because sweet almonds still have a very small amount of amygdalin in them, which can release HCN. I don't think it's enough to smell in open air, but in your mouth it can be concentrated enough to be detected at the back of the nose. It's subtle, but it is definitely part of the flavor profile. So, while I still don't think it's accurate to say that it smells like almonds, for some people, it might be similar to the taste. To make that connection though, the person needs to a) be able to smell HCN and b) be particularly aware of that part of the flavor.

I can smell the HCN, but I never noticed it in the flavor of almonds, so I didn't make the connection. I was even looking for a similarity and eating almonds at the same time, but never noticed it. It was only when I became very familiar with the smell of HCN that I started noticing it in almonds. What's interesting too, is that now after noticing it, I feel like I've started to associate the smell with almonds. It's no longer just a "chemical" smell and it feels more almondy. However, on the flip side, I feel like almonds taste worse and are more "chemically."

But either way, I still don't think that saying it smells like almonds or bitter almonds is accurate or helpful. However, based on the messages I've received, some people are naturally associating cyanide with almonds (sometimes without knowing that this was even a thing and not even knowing they were smelling cyanide). This has piqued my interest and I think it could be fun to get to the bottom of this and to do a trial with a lot more people.

So, you know how you said that a LOT of people can't smell cyanide, even at toxic levels? Well, fun fact, just like there are people for whom cilantro tastes horrible, there's also a VERY small portion of the population who are actually MORE sensitive to cyanide and can end up tasting the trace levels present even in sweet almonds. In the worst of cases, though I've never actually heard of an incident where this happened, it's theoretically possible for a person who's sensitive enough exposed to a large enough quantity of mundane, sweet almonds, to actually experience acute cyanide poisoning. It's such a small portion of the population, you're more likely to find someone who's outright just allergic to almonds than someone with the cyanide hypersensitivity. I think the actual number is around 1/20000 but that might be a bit generous...

I’m not, actually, sure that Cyanide is the right poison to be sniffing. I suspect the literary poison is Nitrobenzene. I’d love to see you run a (safe) experiment with that as a follow-up.

I think that references to the smell of bitter almonds in detective literature are literally referring to the (at least literary, if not historical) use of Oil of Bitter Almonds (which used to be a much more common article; familiar to readers) as a poison. I guess I never thought that anyone was saying that pure Prussic Acid smells like almond oil, but that the, extremely aromatic, Oil of Bitter Almond (not the bland nut oil used for paint and wood sealing, nor the essential oil we are more familiar with, but Nitrobenzene marketed as Oil of Bitter Almond) was the poison being used. The synthetic Oil of Bitter Almond was sold as a fragrance. It was used in soaps and shoe polishes, and in all sorts of concoctions where an unpleasant volatile chemical needed to be masked.

In a concentrated form Nitrobenzene/Oil of Mirbane is very toxic. It’s not, however, Cyanide. It IS a poison. It does (apparently) smell like Almond Extract. Exposure to it blocks absorption of Oxygen, making lips and fingertips turn blue—Cyanosis.

Almonds are associated with Cyanide. Nitrobenzene is associated with Almonds. Cyanosis is associated with poisoning by either—and shares the same (Blue) root word with Cyanide. So, it all gets rolled up together.

Mystery writers need not be chemists (nor YouTube commentators! I am no Chemist!).
Though, Rex Stout is kind enough to explain that the Oil of Bitter Almond used as a poison in The Red Box is not, actually, cyanide—putting me on this train of thought.

I don’t have any experience with Nitrobenzene, so I don’t know to what degree it, actually, smells like almond extract. I think it was a substance that’s mystery readers contemporary to the golden age authors had smelled…and associated with the odor of Almond…and expected to be poisonous.

So, yeah: Almonds don’t “smell like almond.” Not purified cyanide, but “Oil of Bitter Almonds” was associated with poison. And the “Oil of Bitter Almonds people were most likely to have smelled was synthetic.

I might be wrong about all of those points, but that is what I am thinking of when I read about the “smell of bitter almonds” in a novel.

I think that references to the smell of bitter almonds in detective literature are literally referring to the (at least literary, if not historical) use of Oil of Bitter Almonds (which used to be a much more common article; familiar to readers) as a poison. I guess I never thought that anyone was saying that pure Prussic Acid smells like almond oil, but that the, extremely aromatic, Oil of Bitter Almond (not the bland nut oil used for paint and wood sealing, nor the essential oil we are more familiar with, but Nitrobenzene marketed as Oil of Bitter Almond) was the poison being used. I don’t have any experience with Nitrobenzene, so I don’t know to what degree it, actually, smells like almond extract. I think it was a substance that’s mystery readers contemporary to the golden age authors had smelled.

So, yeah: Almonds don’t “smell like almond.” Not purified cyanide, but “Oil of Bitter Almonds” was associated with poison. And the “Oil of Bitter Almonds people were most likely to have smelled was synthetic.

I might be wrong about all of those points, but that is what I am thinking of when I read about the “smell of bitter almonds” in a novel.

I’m a little bit mystified why, when told that something “smells like almonds,” you would try sniffing shelled, roasted snack almonds or processed almond “milk;” which are the least aromatic forms of almonds. I do understand that almonds are now a common snack food and we encounter them less often in other forms—but Agatha Christie did not much on Diamond Brand almonds. :) I would agree with you that a bag of roasted almonds does not “smell like almonds.”

I think that references to the smell of bitter almonds in detective literature are literally referring to the (at least literary, if not historical) use of Oil of Bitter Almonds (which used to be a much more common article; familiar to readers) as a poison. I guess I never thought that anyone was saying that pure Prussic Acid smells like almond oil, but that the, extremely aromatic, almond oil (not the bland oil used for paint and wood sealing, but the essential oil marketed as Oil of Bitter Almond) was the poison being used.

The "burnt almond" smell is from lead acid batteries getting contaminated with sea water.

A whole lot of gasses come out , but the most dangerous is hydrogen cyanide , so sailors ( especially submariners) are taught that if they smell "burning almonds" it means hydrogen cyanide is present.

And yes , I experienced it first hand on two occasions and to me it smelled like a cross between almonds and bleach.

*the first time was when someone re-filled a battery with the ships firemain water ( sea water ) instead of condensate ( pure water ) the second time we never figured out how it happened.

I believe the main source of the smell of almonds is from the hydrogen sulfide and ozone that also produced.

The signs of cyanide toxicity at concentrations leading to death in humans are well described.
Intoxication at ≥2,000 ppm hydrogen cyanide is characterized by a brief sensation of dryness and burning
in the throat due to local irritation, a suffusing warmth, and a hunger for air. Hyperpnea, and sometimes a
brief outcry, follows the first breath. In <1 minute, apnea, a few gasps, loss of consciousness, and
convulsions occur. Cardiovascular failure may also occur, although the heart may continue to beat for 3–
4 minutes after the last breath. Reported signs sometimes include a bitter almond-like odor on the breath
and (in light-toned individuals) a rose-colored hue of the skin.

Many fruit trees in the apple, pear, ....plum, prune, peach, apricot, almond,....& citrus families , have cyanide in the seeds, skin, leaves and wood.  Modern sweet almonds have been bred to eliminate most of the almond aroma and flavor which was quite noticeable even in sweet almonds, 50 years ago.  This was close to the flavor of Jordan Almonds , or amaretto . To get a strong idea of what Hydrocyanic Acid tastes and smells like chew on a tangerine seed or an apple seed.   Then spit it out,... or to be safe, just remember having done that, and how unpleasant it was.   This strong bitter repugnant taste becomes more fragrant and mild when cooked for some time in the presence of sugar or starches.  It then becomes very reminiscent of "almond " or "cherry" flavor,.  apricot, and prune pits, have pretty much the same effect.  Roasting them apparently changes the cyanide enough that it is not so dangerous.  It is unwise to use wooden bowls made from the wood of these trees for food..  Lots of types of wild cherries are toxic also.  If You take the leaves of a cherry tree, and break it by folding, it 1st has the strong cyanide odor, but if You roll it between Your fingers for 20 seconds or so, it begins to smell like almond oil flavor.

Here in Italy bitter almonds are still uncommon but very available. Not that I eat them everyday, but I like ‘em more than the regular sweet ones.

I live in Spain, on the Mediterranean coast, and we have a bunch of almond trees. But most importantly... Spanish almonds are super sweet, and are also the same classes that were brought to America. But in Turkey they have bitter ones that the Germans love for some reason... But even Turkey's bitter almonds are not as bitter as regular wild almonds. (and I'm afraid those are the ones you got)
You see... Almonds in their natural state are the most bitter thing in existence. And to get a sweet almond, you must splice the roots of a new almond sapling with a branch of an already sweet almond tree. So, modern almonds are the result of thousands of years of selection by farmers.

So if you want some truly bitter almonds, find some raw almonds, plant them, and wait a few years. Or go looking for an almond tree growing on the side of the road.

So when it comes to the smell of toxins repelling you it is an evolutionary mechanism. Crudely speaking if there is a gene that causes your sense of smell to sense a toxin as smelling bad and thus make you avoid it the person with that gene will be more likely to survive, reproduce and that gene will proliferate in the gene pool. With less common toxins this effect will not occur as we would rarely come into contact with it in our evolutionary history.

We only evolve to be able to detect poisons that we're exposed to. People are exposed to hydrogen sulphide from rotting plant matter and bad eggs, so it's advantageous to be repelled by that, so we evolved to recognize it as a bad smell. I can't think of any situation in which people are exposed to cyanides, so there's no pressure to evolve a way of detecting them. They just trigger whatever random set of receptors in our noses and that generates whatever smell it happens to generate.

I think the saying that cyanide 'smells like almonds' came about because cyanide gas is produced when stomach acid and the macerated seeds of either Bitter Almond, apricot, peach, and apple trees, and cassava root pulp are combined. I have heard it said that the action of consuming the seeds from 50-100 bitter almonds can produce enough cyanide gas to kill the average sized, 150-180 lb. adult human. One would have to crush and comsume them very quickly to get enough poison gas to kill, however. Bitter almonds are from the Bitter Almond Tree. Both are banned from sale in the States for this reason. Sweet almonds are from another genus of tree. These do not have poisonous enzymes in them and they can be readily purchased. Bitter almonds are used to make almond extract. If you've tasted ALMOND EXTRACT, you know now know what bitter almonds taste like. Two crushed bitter almonds are enough to flavor 1 cake or a batch of almond cookies. There are reports occasionally in the China Morning Sun that children in China and/or other parts of Asia and the Philippines are killed because they consume improperly cooked cassava root. This root must be cooked long and slow. It is time and heat that destroys the enzyme that combines with stomach acids to make the cyanide gas.

In some analogue photographic processes (wet plate photography) you also use cyanide as a developer. You especially have to be careful when using the fixer, because fixer is an acid. Letting acid come in contact with the cyanide creates extremely dangerous gasses. But taking acid in account, when eating (bitter)almonds, within the stomach you automatically add the acid environment of the stomach due to its acid nature to the (bitter)almonds that you just ate. Only in very large quantities this could become dangerous. Especially for smaller animals as they have less body weight. So animals eating (bitter)almonds are much more likely to die of a possible cyanide poisoning than a human would. So you were safe eating the (bitter)almonds.

There is some traditional stuff in Europe that still has the original taste, for example "Amaretto" liqueur or "Marzipan" sweets.

Because Nile doesn't explain it, allow me: Cyanide is dangerous because it literally replaces the functions of oxygen in your blood and it sticks around a lot longer in mitochondria. Effectively the affected body is pushed into necrosis because the cells can't get oxygen anymore. Small amounts are processable by the body but even the smallest amount of "too much" means instant death.

Cyanide is also used in very small amounts in cigarettes, it's one of the reasons why it gives that tingly pleasant sensation when smoking. That's for the same reason why we find spice and nightshade pleasant, tissue gets damaged but no so damaged that it gets destroyed, for some reason that's pleasant, don't ask me. It could have something to do that cells use it to destroy other, unhealthy, cells but that's speculation.

Also the reason Nile keeps saying he keeps smelling cherries is because, like almonds, they contain relatively high cyanide levels. The other guys probably never ate many cherries or their "holy shit it's poison" receptors are just more attuned to chlorine, but that's what's happening, receptors yelling: "It's poison gtfo." Never eat the seeds of trees, they all contain cyanide and it's never healthy.

If you or someone you know needs a reason to quit smoking then do some research into cyanide. It sure made my hat fall off just to know how much damage it does to living cells and by extent the entire body. It's no wonder scientists are warning against the side effects of smoking. You kill so many cells so quickly it's insane. At the same time I also figured out how resilient the human body is so that was a plus.

Jewelry manufacturing firms (not your local jewelry store) frequently use a technique/process referred to as "Bombing" it involves placing the finished karat gold (usialy 10-14 karat .416 or .585 purity of gold) jewelry products (especially machine made chains and earrings or other product made using factory production technique.
The cyanide bombing process ilikley gets its name from the step that involves adding the dry cyanide to the solution in a large container with the gold jewelry under a fume hood hopefully all in one moment the batch foams or froths as if a small explosion (no flame),
Now the jewelry has its its outer surface layer purified to 24karat or pure gold.
It gives uniformity to the particular ye)ow color of the product, being that the gold content is standard yet the alloy recipies differ greatly. But when new it all will seem to have the same alloy color due to this technique.

As part of an scientific endeavor I was heating up some soot in waste water from a soot factory at my laboratory as a part of an attempt to analyse the content, especially for metals and such, when a co-worker came by and began to cough and warned me for the toxic fumes coming of the open container. I could however smell nothing, but after a second alarmed co-worker making clear it was  no joke I transferred the lot into a fume hood and analysed the fumes with a Dräger kit for toxic gasses. It was a high amount of hydrogen cyanide! But I could not smell it, so now I knew: I was smell deaf for HCN. Further investigations on the stuff where performed in a fume hood with adequate ventillation, of course :)

Here's an interesting medical fact for anyone that might be cofused. Not everyone can smell almonds. The specific smell receptors are genetically passed on by non-mandelian inheritence, and just like rolling your tongue or having hair on earlobes, not everyone has the smell receptors to smell almonds. It's one of those weird facts you learn in medical college.
It has some importance in forensic medicine. There was a tme when criminals used cyanides for homicide. When mixed with food, it often goes undetected because many people simply can't smell it.
This is why he smelled absolutely nothing despite directly smelling so many crushed almonds.

I had a cylinder of 10ppm hydrogen cyanide in nitrogen for calibrating cyanide detectors, it smelled a lot like marzipan only stronger. I was calibrating detectors in an electroplating workshop, they had cyanide in the plating baths. Before going in the plating bath the object to be plated was cleaned in acid then washed but the risk of acid getting into the bath was still there.

Another natural source of cyanide is laurel leaves. If you take a laurel leaf and scrumple it up in your hand then smell it there is an overwhelming odour of chlorophyll but behind the chlorophyll is a faint odour of cyanide.
Leaving the scrumpled laurel leaf in a sealed container for thirty minutes or so allows the concentration to build and its quite pungent when you open the container.
Apparently, a laurel leaf contains enough cyanide to kill a yellow jacket/wasp.

I've always thought that people who say cyanide smells like almonds meant it smells like almond extract, used in baking, not the dried or roasted nuts themselves. Furthermore, I suspect that the cyanide they were smelling had been obtained from almonds, rather than cyanide that had been chemically synthesized. When extracted from bitter almonds, the cyanide would be contaminated by benzaldehyde, a byproduct of the breakdown of amygdalin. What they're really smelling is the benzaldehyde, which is the source of the smell in almond extract, maraschino cherries, and the liqueur Amaretto. The sodium cyanide you used had probably been synthesized, and was free of benzaldehyde.

I wonder how much amygdalin is still present in the dried, packaged nuts. If you want to pursue this line of inquiry further, try cracking open a peach pit, and smashing up the fresh, moist nut inside. I've gotten a benzaldehyde smell from that.

Actually, the characteristic 'cyanide' smell from almonds is stronger if you smell green (unripen) almonds (especially from almonds that you'll find in peaches or prunes fresh seeds). You can smell it as well from unripen apple seeds. Most of almonds are sold dried and probably the drying or 'cooking' process is deactivating HCN release.  When you are drying or frying/gril them, you are probably destroying the HCN source, therefore you won't smell the subtle smell coming out from it.

Back when criminals were executed by hydrogen cyanide gas in a "gas chamber", the witnesses to the execution in the next room all reported smelling almonds.    This is particularly surprising because the gas chamber was tested to be airtight.  It is apparent the almond smell is not from the hydrogen cyanide gas alone as they were smelling in this video; but it is generated when the hydrogen cyanide mixes and reacts with the atmosphere.  I am guessing when it reacts with oxygen.

If you wonder, what cyanide (or rather hydrocyanic acid) smells like: cook a bunch of legumes that are unsafe to eat raw, like lima beans or chickpeas. They're unsafe to eat raw, because they contain cyanogenic glucosides. Those break down into sugars and hydrocyanic acid, when cooked or when the legume is damaged. The acid then dissolves in the cooking water and partially evaporates during cooking. That typical unpleasant "raw legume taste" and "cooking legume smell" that can cause head aches and migraines .. that's the hydrocyanic acid.

I was typing out an entire response, about how it's bitter almonds specifically, but then you went into it... So I'll say this instead... Only some people can smell cyanide. Also...

Fun fact: Cyanide works by interfering with the ATP cycle of your cells, directly causing cellular apoptosis. That's a fancy term that here means "shuts your cells off like a light switch".

Funner fact: Garlic, onions, and other alliums contain a compound that also interferes with the ATP cycle in the exact opposite manner as cyanide. This is why they're highly poisonous to dogs, cats, etc. BUT... humans can eat them just fine. And since it operates in the exact opposite manner, eating insane amounts of garlic, onions, leeks, shallots, etc will actually make you resistant to cyanide poisoning. That's resistant, not immune, and I don't know how long it takes for the resistance to kick in, nor do I know how long it takes. So don't go testing your luck with that.

NileRed, I was in the pharma industry 40 years ago. We used sodium cyanide in some of our compounding. The the chemists were concerned about gassing off and devised a test to see if the workers could smell almonds (yes, sweet almonds like cookies). The test sample was prepared as you did with the cyanide dissolved in water.  In fact, Most of us compounders could smell almonds as low as 10ppm concentrations. Come to find out, most of us were smokers. The non smokers could not even smell it at 50ppm. Please revisit this with some cigarette smokers.

Nitrobenzene also smells "sweet" but with a pungent by-taste. During my undergraduade studies i often had to work with these substances and very often i was not sure if i smell benzaldehyde or nitrobenzene but i always was sure when i smelled cyanide. The famous "pool-smell" were in most cases nitrous gases, here most proment nitrogen dioxide...

I think the important distinction with evolved bad smells are things that are likely to cause death when ingested. For instance, hydrogen sulfide is very naturally occuring and lethal at very low concentrations, methane is common, etc.

The issue with cyanide though is that it’s not exactly “common”, amygdalin is present is many things but rarely ever at a dangerous concentration. You’d need an unreasonable amount of crushed apple seeds, cherry pits, apricot seeds etc. to ever have a lethal does of cyanide so aside from bitter almonds, which even a handful would be a lot to obtain for a primitive human, cyanide poisoning is essentially non-existant so there’s no reason why we’d evolve to avoid the smell of cyanide like we don’t avoid lead salts(which some taste sweet) and radiation.

I think the thing to keep in mind is that the origins of the description of cyanide's smell is from the 1800's (at least) when many if not most of the industrialized smells that we are used to didn't exist. There were no chemically-treated indoor pools or similar chemical smells around that most people were familiar with. Even if some of these smells were around, they were likely not as common for the average person, and so more natural smells are going to be what people's brains jump to associate with. You also mentioned that since this experience, almonds have begun to take on a more chemical scent/ flavor for you. People also used to have a much narrower range of foods to eat, which means that if they ate almost it may well have been that they ate almonds much more frequently than you and in more forms than you do. If you eat a lot of foods infused with the flavor of almonds, then the different flavor combinations and cooking methods can cause different elements of a food's flavor to be highlighted (as well as the fact that if you just eat a lot of something, you will become much more sensitive to the different elements of the flavor and smell of it, much in the same way that someone off the street probably couldn't tell the difference between a $900 dollar bottle of wine and some grape kool-aid mixed with rubbing alcohol whereas a wine connoisseur can probably smell the difference between two different years of the same wine from across the room)

It could also well be that people who work around cyanide for extended periods of time develop a stronger mental association between the two than you have with this short sort of experience. Not to mention that different people are more sensitive to certain smells. Just being able to smell a certain chemical doesn't necessarily mean that you smell it as strongly as the next person or that there aren't other smells that are more or less weak to you than others that could also be influencing your perception (plus the ambient smells where you are could be affecting you, as well) Just because you don't notice the similarity very much just doesn't mean that you should declare the description as "unhelpful", there are way too many other factors at play here to discourage people from using this as one of many methods of detecting a deadly poison.

All compact seeds within a hard shell of a fruit are called almonds, e.g. apricots, sweet and bitter almonds, peaches also pine almonds. In general, walnuts and all other nut varieties are also almonds.

Evidently, the subjectiveness of each individual's sense of smell and taste can make this experiment very tricky. But I happen to work in an electroplating factory that deals with large volumes of hot Potassium Cyanide solutions for gold plating and stripping. It's a separate sealed room on the factory floor and I wish you could smell it when we open it up first thing in the morning, after being closed all night. The odor definitely is very almond/nutty (my boss describes it even as sweet) and a bit acid like you suggested, I also think there's some chlorine-like burn sensation on the nose. The first time I smelled it, it instantly reminded me of crushed almonds, the whole nut does not have the same smell. Maybe try crushing or grinding the almonds and you'll see the odor really shows up!

Another thing is you used NaCN. Do you think there's a different interaction from NaCN to KCN in regards to the smell? Do you think you can check it on a future experiment?

I don’t know if you’ll see this comment but i work at a nut roasting company, and i’ve noticed the raw untreated almonds taste extremely chemical like, specifically mildew, chlorine or bleach, i don’t really find them to smell as bitter or as strong as they taste, (mind you i’ve opened 150# plastic barrels of them) i think them being raw is a significant factor, i always assumed the taste was a byproduct of the steam treatment they go through to kill bacteria, i’d never heard this rumor till now.  Update, it also occurred to me there are a few different varieties or “crop” of almond we get, the cheaper and smaller “18/20”s or “Whole and broken” almonds have the chemical taste whereas more expensive redskins or carmels have a much sweeter and more natural tasting flavor

I get hydrogen cyanide for entomology by chopping up some leaves of cherry laurel (Prunus laurocerasus), a common hedge plant in the same genus as almond, and placing them at the bottom of a small container. The smell gets super strong.

I usually put a little bit of toilet paper on top and insect specimens tend go die quite soon after they're put in.

You can leave specimens in the tube for ages too as the cyanide keeps them flexible after death and stops fungi from growing.

Nah, just like you said, almonds smell like nothing until you eat them. I kept editing this comment as I went deeper into your video because you explained most of the bitter almond composition, amygdalin content and how it decomposes into glucose, benzaldehyde and hydrocyanic acid (HCN). Now, you would need to ingest between 1.6 and 3 kilograms of bitter almonds for a lethal dose of cyanide depending on their concentration, so it is a huge amount for just a try. You can also find cyanide in different kernels, like apricot and peach kernels, and those are easier to find. And I agree with you, it is misleading because you would not "smell cyanide" just out of the bag, you need to crush it and hydrate it, at least with saliva.
Moreover, I guess "almond smell" comes from almond oil (that can also be purchased), which only stands out when they are pressed in your mouth and hydrated with saliva. Also in that essence you showed in the video because of the almond oil diluted in alcohol.

Saliva contains enzymes that split off sugars. By splitting off the sugar component of the benzaldehyde it drives the cyanide production reaction faster.

The plant has benzaldehyde to discourage animals from eating its seeds. No need to have cyanide until the seed is eaten, and elegantly, eating is used to create the cyanide.

I was cleaning out a jeweler's lab once and got a good whiff of cyanide from a poorly labeled plating solution. Smelled nothing like almonds; my first reaction was 'chemical! poison!'. Bleach is as good a description as anything. My windpipe reflexively constricted, your body knows it doesn't want that stuff.
I got out of there, made sure I was around someone to make a hospital run if needed. A couple hours and I was fine. I later neutralised the solution with bleach.

Actually spending time in lab often leads to worsened smell, I dont have papers to prove it, only my own observations. None of my friend who study and use labs daily have good smell  (turning on old fume hood takes too long so they end up inhaling a lot of not too dangerous stuff by accident). I have expanded chemistry but it often really ends only on paper due to limited funds, so when I get a chance my curiosity takes a hold of me. So when I was making some complex salts and highly concentrated ammonia was required (and such stuff is given by the lab guardian) as soon as I walked away I sniffed it by waving my hand towards me. I started coughing right away, my eyes, nose and throat were in slight pain. Meanwhile my friend (who uses lab almost every day) checked what I have (by sniffing it aswell) and said "oh, it kicks first time eh?" while I kept coughing for few more minutes. He doesnt smell well outside of the lab aswell, Im always the first one to smell when there is some bbq party nearby. And for me almonds have decent amount of smell to them, with very slight tint of possibly water evaporating from pool. I would like to see some further tests with ppl who have no idea what they are smelling to name the smell (possibly with few ppl not affiliated with labs)

I used to work somewhere that used loads of potassium cyanide in a process of heat treating metal. The reaction led to an ammonia vapor off-product and it was the worst thing imaginable. Before the ventilation was fixed there, on a bad day, if you walked by the line after the operators dumped the salt in, you’d nearly pass out because the ammonia was so strong. I’ll pass on anything cyanide related in the future.

On the CDC site you pictured it says that some people can't smell it. You may be among those. So, I propose the following experiment:

1. Get the plastic container up to at least 40ppm to account for dispersion in an outdoors environment.
2. Walk outside, walk up to a person at random and hold it under their nose.
3. Ask "What does this cyanide smell like to you?" (Do NOT mention almonds, you don't want to bias them)
4. Repeat at least 25 times for a statistically significant result.

WARNING: This experiment could lead to grievous bodily injury or death (yours, and probably not from the cyanide). But remember, in the words of a great scientist "We do what we must because we can."

PS: It is well known that cops can't smell almonds. Testing them will likely lead to an unsatisfyingly unfinished experiment, so you should avoid them.

Title: Full of cyanide

IMPOTANT NOTE1: I have revised my opinion about what it smells like. In the video, I said it was like an indoor pool and I correlated it to the chlorine. However, I think it's more accurate to say the pool locker room or shower. It is musty/moldy, with a background of pool smell.

IMPORTANT NOTE2: After posting this video, I got a few messages from people saying that in their experience, cyanide DOES smell like almonds. So, I spent an hour tonight doing some tests, and I think the results are interesting. I did some direct comparisons and the smell of cyanide is distinctly different from the smell of almonds. However, if I EAT the almonds, there is sometimes a faint taste of cyanide. I think this is because sweet almonds still have a very small amount of amygdalin in them, which can release HCN. I don't think it's enough to smell in open air, but in your mouth it can be concentrated enough to be detected at the back of the nose. It's subtle, but it is definitely part of the flavor profile. So, while I still don't think it's accurate to say that it smells like almonds, for some people, it might be similar to the taste. To make that connection though, the person needs to a) be able to smell HCN and b) be particularly aware of that part of the flavor.

I can smell the HCN, but I never noticed it in the flavor of almonds, so I didn't make the connection. I was even looking for a similarity and eating almonds at the same time, but never noticed it. It was only when I became very familiar with the smell of HCN that I started noticing it in almonds. What's interesting too, is that now after noticing it, I feel like I've started to associate the smell with almonds. It's no longer just a "chemical" smell and it feels more almondy. However, on the flip side, I feel like almonds taste worse and are more "chemically."

But either way, I still don't think that saying it smells like almonds or bitter almonds is accurate or helpful. However, based on the messages I've received, some people are naturally associating cyanide with almonds (sometimes without knowing that this was even a thing and not even knowing they were smelling cyanide). This has piqued my interest and I think it could be fun to get to the bottom of this and to do a trial with a lot more people.

Just a couple weeks ago I accidentally had a whiff of HCN after I accidentally mixed a (very) dilute solution of ferricyanide and sulfuric acid (again, very dilute) while pouring them in a waste container. It did have a... strange smell to say the least. At least for me it did actually kinda reminded me of almonds and the smell, although made me crap myself, was actually enjoyable. While I do not know what the concentration the inhaled HCN had, it did make both my legs and hands go numb after about 20 minutes. The effect lasted for around four hours. This really shows that in general HCN has a numbing effect on muscles in general, as it was in case of your tongue. I was basically symptomless after around four and a half hours after the initial exposure and I did not have any side effects at all. But I bought some almond flavoured cleaning solutions for my bathroom coz I bloody love that smell now.

People are always panicky when they hear the word cyanide, but often don't realize that azide and H2S are equally potent toxicity wise. You want to know what cyanide smells like, accurately? You were not far off when you were talking about chlorine or bleachy type chemical smell. Get yourself some green Granny Smith apples, or Honeycrisp, or red delicious apples that are still early and not mealy,  just like fully ripened and  just. Any of these will work as they have a good concentration of amygdalin. Chew them well and you will notice a slightly bleachy odor/taste in your mouth but also kind of like bitter almonds. And in fact to be fair, if you eat 200 apple seeds in this manner, you will consume enough cyanide to absorb a fatal dose.

If you want to know what that smells or tastes like, eat the nut inside a peach or apricot pit. It looks like an almond, has the amygdalin compound, and has been used in treating cancer. Cancer data is mixed, and higher doses are toxic to the liver (main detox organ) and can kill you. It has been called laetrille and vitamin B-17 (not a vitamin!). There are other natural substances that are likely better for cancer treatments. It's usually easier to find a peach or nectarine than a kilo of cyanide at Sprawl Mart.

Decades ago, my inorganic chemistry professor had some cyanide accidents. In one of them, H2SO4 was accidentally poured into a NaCN bath, without anyone knowing what the solution actually contained.

My professor was there when it started reacting. She said she immediately felt a strong almond odor, that it was pleasant and therefore she didn't worry about it. Only after a few minutes she saw her reflection in a mirror, saw her skin was red. She passed out moments later.

Today she's pretty much well and alive, but her cyanide stories are always a thrill.

I worked a lot with cyanide when I worked as research metallurgist in the gold mining industry in South Africa. It is fairly harmless when you have it in solution and keep the pH high enough. Gold leaching is done around pH 10. One day I was alone in my lab around lunchtime and for some reason I wanted to make copper cyanide in solution. So I mixed sodium cyanide solution with copper sulphate solution, forgetting that copper sulphate solution is slightly acidic, depending on the concentration, a pH between 4 and 5. That was the only time in my 17 years working with cyanide that I actually got to smell it. I was on my own in the lab and I was pretty scared, although the small amount was unlikely to have done any harm.

Nice video!!! I think that one of the things you've missed here is that, in the majority, the cyanide/almond smell thing comes from old school white European detective writers, scientists, and people.

I have an Italian background. In Italy the almond is called "mandorla". There are a whole host of food products, from cakes and their icing (think marzipan ... eeeuuuwww), to biscuits (cookies to you), to alcoholic drinks, and etc, that are "mandorlato", or "almonded". I have never understood how anyone could eat or drink that stuff, even with the sugar and/or alcohol involved.

Hey, I worked at a plating company for a year. We had thousands of liters of silver and gold cyanide baths for plating. It definitely has a very distinct odor. I also knew it beforehand from bitter almond extract. But it's not really helpful tbh. When HCN levels get really critically high the smell vanishes. I sometimes noticed this when dropping multiple bags of 2.5kg KCN in silver baths. I used masks for it ofc. Also, as you mentioned, half of the staff couldn't smell the HCN itself. We relied on detectors.

With a kg of CN lying around you could do some pretty fun stuff plating pennies and stripping old electronics for precious metals. Ah yeah also: The body is able to metabolize CN, so taking in low dosages is ok. The toxic effect is prohibiting your cells from taking O2. So if you stay on low levels it doesn't do that much. I think it only really took off as a known poison because people a hundred years ago had it in photography kits available and it dissolves easily. Well and.. you know. The Holocaust.

After watching this video, I gotta say, I don't like it at all, here are my points:

The toxicity of cyanide compounds is less about the volume and more about how quick it kills you. It blocks the cytochrome-c-oxidase and effectively stops a body cell from producing ATP which kills it instantly. The result is a mass death of cells which will inevitably is fatal. If you take a lethal dose of cyanide it will kill you more quickly than a lethal dose of an average poison. Given a large enough dose, you would get unconscious while swallowing and be dead before you hit the floor.

Also it smells like almonds because almonds contain cyanides. To get the smell you have to roast them, not just crush them up and mix them with water. The concentration is too low to produce enough HCN for you to smell. Eating a lot of bitter almonds or roasted almonds can kill you, truthfully only if you ingest ridiculous amounts (upwards of 1kg) but they still contain a toxic compound. I feel like you should not downplay that.

You are probably part of the population that is not able to smell cyanide. Hence, you only detect the other smells that are usually overshadowed by the cyanide. I smelled it a few times when having a whiff of stomach content of someone being poisoned with cyanide during the post mortem. It is very distinctive and smell exactly like the stuff (bitter almond flavor) you can buy to put into you cakes or pudding. But not all people can smell it. It's a genetic trait that affects 25-50% of the population. I think, you can't smell it and what you thought was the smell of almonds or cyanide you smelled your whole life (that chemical/cherry smell) is something else or even a trick of the mind/nose.

It doesn't surprise me the HCN didn't smell like regular almonds. It's said to smell like bitter almonds. Though most of the smell of bitter almonds is actually from benzaldehyde, the other product of the enzymatic reaction that happens to amygdalin when eating (bitter) almonds. This also explains why they only smell like that when being eaten, becaus the necessary enzyme is in the saliva. I've once tried to make cyanide from pure amygdalin with HCl, but wasn't able to achieve that without the enzyme present. Also, in regular almonds you can sometimes find bitter ones. I've once had a job in a lab where, amongst other things, I had to test almonds for bitter ones by eating a specified amount. Funnily enough I never fond one during this job but in a bought pack of almonds shortly after I left there.
Though being a chemist myself, I didn't ever smell HCN, so I can't say anything about this part.

I think a key message here is how deadly substances can accumulate when it appears that very little is happening - the use of the CN meter illustrates this well. Might have been worth mentioning WHY cyanide is deadly (it blocks respiration in cells).

I got a good whiff of cyanide when I was a kid.  I was in a summer class on entomology, and our teacher had a kill jar for bugs that was filled with cyanide crystals covered by perforated wax.  One time he was transferring a recently killed bug into my bug container (a plastic tub), and a few crystals of it got transferred along with it.  When I got home, I was a bit curious so I took a big whiff and almost instantly vomited and had a pretty nasty headache for a few hours.  It's not something I would want to try again.

Smells of burnt almonds in my experience. I don't know how much I inhaled but I felt unwell enough to trigger the safety procedures (and to warn none of my coworkers to give me CPR if I collapsed - mouth to mouth can poison the rescue-breather).
I began to feel better after about 15 minutes of sitting in fresh air and was attended to.

The exposure occurred while I was opening an autoclave which should have been completely depressurised and had been vented for some time. Unfortunately, the venting port had blocked during the venting process due to the formation of some sticky gunk that must have boiled as the pressure dropped near to ambient. When I released the restraining cuff, a residual puff burped out and got me in the face, despite working in a fume cupboard and having the sash at its lowest point. Fortunately I had done a risk assessment and had identified that HCN was a possible and very unlikely by-product of the reaction but I prepared so I knew what to do.
This is lab safety - expect the unlikely!
If you disrespect the chemistry, you put yourself at risk.

In my chemistry studies our professor let us smell cyanide (HCN that is) from a half filled plastic bottle of KCN. He said, like you mentioned as well, that some KCN always will decompose with moisture, and thus the air above the solid will always contain some HCN. I did smell something, but I was never sure about it, since it just smelled more like any old plastic bottle with chemicals in it. But if I smelled it, it was definitely moldy. Notably, not everyone can smell cyanide, due to genetic reasons! That added to the insecurity of the experience. Another interesting anecdote I heard is, that cyanide can be detected by altering the taste of cigarettes when smoking in an atmosphere containing HCN. No idea if that is true, or if anyone wants to try it out ;).

Modern almond/nuts processing methods are precise to meet certain food standards. Therefor using off the shelf almonds even the organically sourced almonds would result on more questions than answers imho.
I personally theorise that modern almonds do not hold up to the old saying that cyanide has a similar odour.
The same thing can be said to many of the everyday foods we now have access to such as fruits and nuts, etc...
To truly comprehend this old statement, I think it would require further historical research and such on how almonds was harvested and prepared back in the days.
You could even interview the people who work on almond farms since they would probably have more exposure on that subject.
It could even be something as silly as how it was commonly served served back then to people that somehow made a scent resembling this one innocent particular nut which led to many written texts stating so.
Maybe even ask old senior folks on how almonds smell like back in the days and perhaps ask if they knew anything about this old saying that seems to have been forgotten long ago.

So it was true, that the smell you smelled was what associated with almonds, but it was probably never the smell of actual almonds (as we know it today), but the usage of (bitter) almond as medicine.

I used to work with Cyanide. Sodium Cyanide and Potassium Cyanide and both in Laboratory as well as Factory circumstances, just to be clear, so I can speak to more than this video for sure and have been in various forms of it's presence, including when acids have been about it.

It is only arguably true that it 'smells like Almond' or 'doesn't smell like anything'. I'd say simply this, I never called it a 'smell', but there's a definite 'something' people sense in the air even in the presence of it in 'Eggs', rather than powder / free pour forms such as he's playing with.
It may, or may not 'smell' like Almonds to YOU (PARTICULARLY if you don't EAT Almonds, see Note 3, or the husk. See almond syrup for the 'smell' you want to 'sense'), you may 'smell' nothing, however, you MIGHT sense your physical reaction to it's presence (such as a slight increase in your heart rate, which can occur at the faintest waft of the stuff, amongst others), so I'd be interested if you were aware of any faint associated physical 'symptoms' of exposure?.
Where you give the example 'you can't smell salt', whilst this might be true for many, many can 'sense' it, differently, because it's hydroscopic ... the air is dry increasingly with proximity, just as being near the sea can be sensed by many, but still it mostly won't register without the awareness of a possibly presence in mind at the time in considering what you're 'picking up on'.

Basically, in any case, if you're not USED to it ... you've almost certainly got NO chance of figuring out what it is before (should the concentration be sufficient) you're going to be dead. Obviously, I've never had a fatal dose introduced to me, but have insight into fatal cases both accidental as well as deliberate and also a couple of survivors from inhalation and ingestion, all of which I recommend avoidance of, naturally.

Personally, I wouldn't recommend ANYONE ever just farting about with Cyanide. He's right that it isn't easy to accidentally fatally dose yourself unless you're an irresponsible idiot, but it happens that people are quite capable of sufficient complacency and stupidity.
I wouldn't be broadcasting my owning a KILO of Sodium Cyanide though, or it's location and ponder what you'll be doing, safely, with the surplus.

Use your sodium cyanide to extract some gold from ore rocks.

Sodium cyanide is used industrially across the globe, most frequently in the mining of gold. Although most of us have the traditional imagery of a 19th-century gold miner panning for nuggets, this isn’t the industrial method used today. Most of the world’s gold is not found in nugget form but as very fine gold powders in rocks. In fact, our cultural demand for gold forces us to mine in rocks that can be as low as 0.005% gold. This means we need industrial extraction to separate and purify gold from all the other materials. After mining and milling, the crude rock mixture is turned into a fine powder and added to a solution of sodium cyanide. The gold forms strong bonds with cyanide molecules and can then be separated from the rest of the minerals because it is then soluble in water. It then reacts with zinc and turns back into a solid. Finally is smelted to isolate the gold and cast into bars.

IMPOTANT NOTE1: I have revised my opinion about what it smells like. In the video, I said it was like an indoor pool and I correlated it to the chlorine. However, I think it's more accurate to say the pool locker room or shower. It is musty/moldy, with a background of pool smell.

IMPORTANT NOTE2: After posting this video, I got a few messages from people saying that in their experience, cyanide DOES smell like almonds. So, I spent an hour tonight doing some tests, and I think the results are interesting. I did some direct comparisons and the smell of cyanide is distinctly different from the smell of almonds. However, if I EAT the almonds, there is sometimes a faint taste of cyanide. I think this is because sweet almonds still have a very small amount of amygdalin in them, which can release HCN. I don't think it's enough to smell in open air, but in your mouth it can be concentrated enough to be detected at the back of the nose. It's subtle, but it is definitely part of the flavor profile. So, while I still don't think it's accurate to say that it smells like almonds, for some people, it might be similar to the taste. To make that connection though, the person needs to a) be able to smell HCN and b) be particularly aware of that part of the flavor.

I can smell the HCN, but I never noticed it in the flavor of almonds, so I didn't make the connection. I was even looking for a similarity and eating almonds at the same time, but never noticed it. It was only when I became very familiar with the smell of HCN that I started noticing it in almonds. What's interesting too, is that now after noticing it, I feel like I've started to associate the smell with almonds. It's no longer just a "chemical" smell and it feels more almondy. However, on the flip side, I feel like almonds taste worse and are more "chemically."

But either way, I still don't think that saying it smells like almonds or bitter almonds is accurate or helpful. However, based on the messages I've received, some people are naturally associating cyanide with almonds (sometimes without knowing that this was even a thing and not even knowing they were smelling cyanide). This has piqued my interest and I think it could be fun to get to the bottom of this and to do a trial with a lot more people.

so when I was younger, my step-dad bought a small airport at a county sheriff's auction. Some guy apparently scammed a bunch of money, stole a plane and left the country.
Anyway, as we are going through all the stuff (lots of weird stuff mixed in with various types a mining and gold recovery gear), I found a bunch of maybe 20 gallon drums. I opened the one that already had the seal broken and for some reason, reached in and grabbed a handful of the powder. I look at it smell it....whatever. Then I look on the side at the faded label. It says CYOGRAN. Granulated cyanide. I didn't know nearly as much about chemistry as I do now, but I was at least a little worried. My parents either weren't worried, or were secretly hoping I would die. Now I know to always check powders before playing with them, especially in a place that is obviously dealing with gold mining and refining.

These drums were just thick cardboard with the cyanide in a plastic bag. I would love to go back in time and measure the air in that building with that meter. Also to grab one of those drums for myself. I have no idea what the hell I would do with it, but I can't be the only one addicted to collecting unusual and somewhat hazardous chemicals.

I don't think anyone's been "mislead" by this saying. All it's for is a way of giving people something they could possibly relate to (the smell of bitter almonds) in order have some idea or frame of reference for the smell of cyanide being described. The smell would also be much more potent in a cyanide pill for suicide, because it's far more concentrated than that faint whisp of gas you're creating. Also, while almonds do have a very faint smell, you're clearly either using old stale almonds or your sense of smell isn't very good (possibly from sniffing cyanide and things). They smell slightly woody, starchy and sweet (not the bitter ones).

Pure and highly diluted, and I can say I’ve heard that myth a million of times from usually new employees, and I can say that it does not smell like any foods. BUT if you have a what we call a “cyanide pregnant solution” that just means we have leeched the ore out and now we are letting it sit before processing it does have a Oder of like bread, but not majorly. To put the sodium cyanide to to "reasonable" use, you could do some advanced chemistry to build one of my favourite organic molecules: Pentacyanocyclopentadiene! A nice little molecule that has a C-H bond more acidic than sulfuric acid. Picture that!

Or, if you want to be a bit more mundane, combine the very toxic sodium cyanide with similarly toxic and also explosive azide salts to make tetrazoles. Or just use it in nucleophilic substitutions to make some interesting nitriles. Which you could then convert to amines or amides or carboxylic acids, as part of a multistep synthesis.

I live in southern France and there is bitter almond trees EVERYWHERE, I eat almonds on the trees every autumn so I think it depends on the place you live : you live in canada and you must never have eaten a bitter almond in your childhood by accident like everybody here.
So I reproduced your experience : took 2 bitter almonds from previously identified trees, crushed them in a 200 mL distilled water beaker of which I covered the top with a watch glass
Then I prepared a very dilute benzaldehyde solution in water (2 drops in 200 mL) to smell and compare the two.
Conclusion : the bitter almonds smells like ... almonds and benzaldehyde and I was unable to distinguish another component in that smell. So HCN smells like almonds.
Furthermore, I know the smell of HCN and it is very very similar of that of benzaldehyde. So I think those smell are associated in my brain to that of almonds because I live with almonds all the time

What water was used? The dilute H₂SO₄ (HSO₄-) may have reacted with something other than the NaCN (HSO₄- + NaCN → HCN + NaSO₄), and the NaCN may have reacted with other things as well, that you have not considered to produce the "chlorine pool smell."

As an example: Simple distillation of water does not remove chlorine, as its ΔTb is lower than that of water. Chlorine will react with HSO₄ ( 2HSO₄ + Cl₂ → 2HCl + 2SO₄) and NaCN (NaCN + Cl₂ → CNCl + NaCl)... what would be the combined smell of Cyanide, Cyanogen chloride, Hydrogen Chloride, sulfur, and salt? From what I remember from toxicology as part of my EMT training decades ago, the whole "Smells like almonds" thing is an after taste of almonds, as in almond paste, after you've ingested a dose. After taste isn't quite the right word for it because it's definitely a "smell" you're experiencing. I will admit that they didn't say if it was "Sweet Almonds" or "Bitter Almonds" but to be honest, I don't think it matters because it triggers the memory of an "almond smell" and "tasting" is very memory-subjective as it is.
I don't recall how much of a dose needed to be ingested to get that sensation. Potential safety note: on one of your meter-in-box runs you're making your safety vulnerable to a single point of failure. When you mash up a whole bunch of the bitter almonds, mix them with water and put them in the box with the meter, your safety is now reliant on the meter's accuracy, with no backstop. With the single (small) crystal of NaCN and with the single bitter almond, you have the backstop of a limited worst-case quantity. I know you didn't sniff at the dozen-almonds box, but the only reason you mentioned (or at least seemed to imply) for not sniffing was the HCN concentration being out of range. Which is fair enough as a reason to not sniff, but I would have liked to see mention of this notion of avoiding single points of failure, somewhere.

So you must try lower concentrations and you must judge the first impression, not the last!

It stands to reason that it doesn't smell like the almonds that you are using because of the volatility of HCN. HCN is a liquid around room temperature, but volatile just above. Our olfactory is extremely sensitive and so you are likely smelling the H2SO4 and maybe Cl from water? If you had a pure sample you would smell the very pleasant pastry/almond odor of "fresh almonds" (the small amount of HCN is obviously volatilized during the roasting process), Please don't try isolating a pure sample; the difference in MW between the basic salt and the parent acid greatly increases the toxicity. Yes there is significant legitimate purpose for these compounds, but smelling them isn't one of them. Be safe and be responsible...

When I was at college, there was an electroplating tank in the chemistry department prep room. This used cyanide as an elctroplating solution. The prep room always had a strong smell of bitter almonds. So as far as I am concerned cyanide does smell of almonds.
The leaves of the Laurel tree, contain significant amounts of cyanide compounds, when crushed the poison is released as a gas. It was used by lepidopterist to kill butterflies and other insects. The crushed leaves of the Laurel were placed in a glass jar, under a layer of cotton wool. Insects placed in this "killing" jar, would succumb to the poison, and rapidly die without their bodies being physically damaged. Crushed Laurel leaves also smell strongly of bitter almonds. The smell does produce a stinging sensation, very similar to chlorine bleach, which maybe why it is described as bitter almonds. The closest most people come to smelling a strong almond scent is from Christmas Cake marzipan,which is flavoured with almond essence. The difference between this and cyanide is the lack of bite and of the threat of imminent death.
If you want to smell almonds, the best way is to buy food grade almond essence.

My experience:
So we have these type of millipede at our backyard, the species is called "Harpaphae Haydeniana", also called the "Almond Smelling Millipede"
This species has a unique defense mechanism, it releases Hydrogen Cyanide gas upon facing predators or after death. I accidentally stepped on one myself and I remember a very unpleasant smell while disposing of the crushed body of the centipede.

Well cyanide has no chronic effects I believe, it either kills you on the spot or you're fine and in for no long term problems, and its one toxic effect is inhibiting cytochrome C, which is basically the enzyme for cellular respiration of all life on Earth. Plus the LD50 (the dose killing 50%) is pretty consistent at about 4 milligrams per kilogram of body weight. So if you weigh about 70 kg or so, try to keep your exposure to 100 milligrams or less and you should be fine unless you've got 1 foot in the grave already. If you consume 300 milligrams, you've got a 50% chance, if you consume half a gram, you've got a 20% chance, and if you consume a gram, unless you have developed a resistance to it from prior exposure to it, say your prayers.

I've found certain people can have varying amounts of olfactory sensitivity. I used a few grams of cyanide in my practical courses for Bachelor's to do a Sandmeyer Reaction. Make Copper(I)cyanide and react it with an aromatic diazonium salt to form an aromatic nitrile compound. In the procedure, the diazonium salt is prepared by reaction of aromatic amine with sodium nitrite in dilute sulfuric acid, the acidic solution is then directly used for reaction with the cyanide. Now this might sound mildly dangerous when you're reading it, and that's exactly what it was. I had two 1L beakers full of an acidic cyanide solution and because Sandmeyer reaction releases Nitrogen (and my cooling was just a normal ice bath) the entire thing was foaming like crazy and spilled over on multiple occasions. There were three main takeaways from that reaction:

1. It worked, clean nitrile after water vapor distillation.
2. Cyanide just kinda smells awful in high concentrations, not at all fruity or almondy.
3. I don't want to do that ever again.

I didn't get any real poisoning symptoms though, so I guess it's fine if you're working in a decent fume hood.

Definitely detectable as a almondy/cherrystone-like aroma for some of us. I used dilute NaCN or KCN as a means of blocking metabolism in yeast cells in a few experiments several years ago. I did notice the aroma very clearly despite the extremely dilute solution.
It is not a very pleasant aroma, and true, not very similar to sweet almonds. But there may be a cognitive connection as there may still exist trace amounts of amygdalin even in sweet almonds. There is also significant amounts of amygdalin present in cherry stones and even apple seeds. I do indeed more associate the CN- ion with the aroma of a bitten off apple seed than that of almonds, but I understand where the notion comes from.

When I was suicidal a few years ago, I searched very very hard for cyanide and could not find any place selling it to the general public. And I’m very very good with the internet (been on it since 1994). The closest I could find were vintage rat traps and similar stuff on eBay under listings that made them fall through the cracks, because obviously cyanide is banned on eBay.

On a related note, I found a recipe used elsewhere in the world for suicide, to make a gas that is so toxic, ONE WHIFF can kill you almost immediately. I though about that one for a long time but felt too concerned about the hazard to whoever found my car (cuz i didnt want my family to be the ones to discover me).

Evidently in the country where this has become a common suicide method, many people tape warning signs to the windows of their car when they do it, so at least the police/EMTs don’t unnecessarily die accidentally.

Finally, if you are fascinated by these toxic gases, check out the most unintentionally entertaining channel on YouTube: YouTube.com/USCSB - the US Chemical Safety Board. Their videos are SO GOOD WE HAVE A NOTIFICATION SQUAD. I’m not shitting you either. They do incredible 3D computer generated ultra detailed recreations of the industrial accident site, better than any I’ve seen anywhere (starting about 1-2 years ago. But even the ones prior to that were really good.) They also have a world class narrator, Sheldon Smith.

The USCSB covers a lot of industrial accidents that involve accidental releases of toxic gases usually resulting in fatalities.

One that has shown up more than once is Phosgene. Holy smokes, that one is one where if you walk into a small puff of it, you’re fucking dead. You’ll know what I mean when you watch the DuPont plant video with the outdoors Phosgene storage shed with the flexible braided stainless hoses that were supposed to be replaced once a month but were left to be 7 months old and corroded.

PS: Watch out if you ever clean something with brake clean, and then weld it. The temperature of welding causes any residual brake clean to generate phosgene. I think this is even printed in the fine print of brake clean spray cans. If you catch a whiff of that, it can kill you. There’s a somewhat widespread-shared magazine article about some badass biker-looking tough guy who told the story how it happened to him and knocked him on his ass and he woke up in the hospital emergency room and the doctor said he was lucky to be alive. I think he had some small but permanent negative side effects after that, too...😳

From the point of view of the smell theory, a (smelly) molecule gets inside one's nose and then finally attaches to a receptor.
The actual feeling of smell depends on, among other factors, how strong the complex "molecule+receptor" is.
At least, the size/shape along with the electronic features of the molecule, are the main smell-determining factors.

So, benzaldehyde smells somewhat similar to nitrobenzene (history tells us, that PhNO2 was once used as a cheap perfume in soaps, as "oil of mirbane", before it was banned because of its toxicity, and replaced with PhCHO).
Both of them do have a benzene ring with 1 functional group, these groups are of comparable size and of electron density maps.

HOW HCN, such a tiny and completely different molecule, COULD be able to smell equally to those?! ;-)

P.S. I've never worked with cyanides, so I didn't encounter the actual smell.
Also, I know, that people's sensitivity to smells, and also their smell-describing abilities, do vary a lot.

A small addition on the toxicity of cyanide:
While cyanide can very quickly kill you in relatively low amounts it isn't very dangerous in repeated low exposure like for this video. Since Cyanide occurs naturally our bodies have gained the ability to quickly neutralise it. This means that you really need to ingest the fatal amount all at once or else it won't be harmful. The cyanide is destroyed within less than 30 seconds to 1 minute.

You could try to make nitroprusside and hexacyanoferrate(II) from the cyanide and do the “pudding test” for sulfites (maybe from white wine or something). Youll need a cold-saturated solution of zinc sulfate, which you mix 1:1 with potassium/sodium hexacyanoferrate(II)-solution. Now put a couple drops of potassium/sodium nitroprusside in and stir. You should get a white pudding-like precipitate of Zn[Fe(CN)6](s). If you drop a couple of drops of your test solution in and there are sulfites in it, the pudding should turn a raspberry-yoghurtish pink from Zn2[Fe(CN)5(NO)SO3](s).

Maybe something that you can try is to get HCN out of ... Vitamin B12. More specifically Cyanocobalamin. It is quiet a fancy molecule and I don't know how you may be able to get it out of it. Little side note: "Normal" B12 is METHYLcobalamin. When you would take B12 suplements with a pathetically low dose (5µg/pill or so) or you have to take the medicinal form (1mg MAX.) ,  you  are in fact pumping CYANOcobalamin in your body. The cyanocobalamin gets converted to a useless form but however, this useless form fooles your intestine so it will absorb a lot more METHYLcobalamin. Keep in mind that administering more than 1mg of the medicinal form it can give you some nasty syptoms (I am not sure that this is becouse of HCN or any CN- ions).

Personally I don't even recall raw almonds having a smell, or particular taste at all (just the "earthy" and maybe a Woody smell, kinda like he smelled on the sweet almonds). A cheap natural way to obtain cyanide is to grind a few almond, apricot or cherry kernels, then soak them in warm water.

All these kernels contain amygdalin, a cyanogenic glycoside, which hydrolyzes in water by the action of plant enzymes, into sugar, benzaldehyde and hydrogen cyanide. The latter compounds can be extracted by distillation.

Doug's lab did this with cherry kernels and actually dissolved some gold leafs in the cyanide-rich water.

You could detoxify the Sodium Cyanide (NaCN) by adding Sodium Hydroxide (NaOH) and Sodium Hypochlorite (NaClo)

Equation:
2 NaCN + 5 NaClO + 2 NaOH => 2Na²CO³ + N² + 5 NaCl + H²O

You can also use Sodium Cyanide for extracting metals or hardening steel.

I think whether you associate the smell of benzaldehyde with almond or cherry depends on whether or not you grew up familiar with the smell of things like Cherry Coke or alternatively Marzipan and almond based sweets flavoured with bitter almond essence. Real living cherries don’t smell of benzaldehyde any more than sweet almonds smell like bitter almonds. Honestly the world of smell perception (which I work in) is less about objective measurables and more about psychological factors and neurological quirks. For instance if your brain is unfamiliar with a specific smell it will literally make you perceive a particular smell as something else which your brain IS familiar with. I experienced this professionally with a perfume ingredient called Galbanum - for years whenever a perfume included real galbanum my brain perceived it as the smell of garlic. My brain with no frame of reference for what Galbanum smelt like simply told my conscious mind that it was smelling garlic. It wasn’t until I had fully familiarised myself with real, raw Galbanum absolute that I relatively suddenly began to smell it as it should be - a bitter, dry, green and vegetal smell that has next to nothing in common with the smell of garlic.

In the case of Cyanide/almond/bitter almond I think there’s a strong case to be made that because much of the cyanide that used to be produced in the historical past was obtained from bitter almonds people began to believe that the smell of cyanide was one and the same as the smell of bitter almond, all the more so since most people would never have smelt strong pure chemical smells all that much in the past. People rarely had access to the kinds of every day chemicals modern people do. Add that to the fact that bitter almond oil was often used to flavour things like marzipan and other sweet almond dishes to boost aroma and add flavour and you end up with an almost universally fixed idea that cyanide smells like “almond”. Nowadays marzipan based foods are less commonly eaten and are not most people’s first point of encounter with a anything that might even be close to having cyanide in it. Instead we are familiar with cleaning chemicals, pool disinfectants, car exhaust fumes, etc etc etc and are readily able to associate smells with the generic “chemical” smell we associate with many of these everyday chemical smell experiences. So it’s probably only natural that to modern noses cyanide no longer smells like bitter almond.

If something is needed to have almond taste/smell, for me the easiest way would be to get some apricots, crush open their stones and get the kernels. That is basically for free, because most people eat the fruit and throw the stones away - the kernels are not used for anything. Apricots are botanically very closely related to almonds and even make hybrids. The apricot kernels are probably somewhere in between of sweet almonds (where the smell is really hard to notice) and bitter (that are too bitter to eat), but that depends a lot on the variety, since apricots were not selected on the basis of their seed edibility and retain the randomness of wild nature. We used to eat a few apricot seeds a day if they are not bitter - 3-4 are safe since they are smaller than almonds. There is amygdalin in the seeds of all other related fruits as well - peaches, plums, cherries, apples etc., although almonds are the largest of them in size and probably more convenient to get in significant total weight. All listed fruit kernels are normally more bitter and toxic than apricots, and not considered edible at all. Even flowers of these plants seem to have a tint of that smell.
I used to work with benzaldehyde a few times - and recognized it as the main essence of the apricot/almond kernel smell. Maybe it is a misunderstanding to assign "almond smell" to HCN while it should be actually assigned to benzaldehyde.

@NileRed the data for 300 ppm and immediate death is completely inaccurate and pretty much a lie, and unfortunately it's perpetrated often because of very problematic testimonies from one historic event that I'll not mention, because it might get flagged.
HCN causes histotoxic hypoxia by inhibiting cytochrome c oxidase, which means your cells are unable to create ATP. This process is completely reversible, and people have enzymes that counter HCN, since it's produced and ingested naturally from various sources.
Because HCN needs to dissociate into tissues through your blood, and it needs to reach high enough levels to be deadly, or be present at certain level long enough to kill you from hypoxia, the death cannot be immediate, and there is always at least couple minutes of lag.
Executions done with HCN in USA took typically ~10 minutes, and concentrations much higher than 300 ppm were used. Typically it was below 1.5% or thereabouts to prevent reaching flammable level, or possible explosion at higher levels. The person in such chamber was also quite directly exposed to HCN vapors, so the concentration they inhaled was even higher than average in the chamber.
Only serious information I was able to find was 2000 ppm causing death in 1 minute, but this also might be slightly exaggerated.

In the 70's the FDA waged total war against an organic cyanide compound, known as nitriloside or amygdalin in the medical community. The result of which was that farmers were forced to grow cultivars of peaches, apricots, walnuts, and other common fruits that lacked the compound. In my Quantitative analysis class, we were told that there is a specific gene in some people that allows them a unique smell for hydrogen cyanide.  Not everyone has the gene.  It is spread about as evenly as the rolling tongue gene.  People with that gene have reported that hydrogen cyanide smells very similar to roasting bitter almonds.  We had one girl say she could smell it during our cyanide lab, but she had just finished alkalizing her cyanide solution so it was nearly impossible that she was actually smelling it since basic cyanide solutions don't have any extra hydrogens for cyanide to party with.  My professor said it more as a fun fact than as a safety tip.  For safety she basically told us, when in doubt, add more NaOH and you wont have to worry about it.

Another curious cyanide fact is that it has pi-backbonding. It can form very strong bonds with metals, because you have d-orbitals in the metal putting electrons in a pi-antibonding orbital on one of the cyanide group's atoms, which can then give it back to the metal, and this goes back and forth.

If you look at a box of salt, it probably has something like sodium hexacyanoferrate in it as an anti-caking agent. This is the sodium salt of Prussian blue, and the strong metal-cyanide bond is why it doesn't dissociate and kill you.

It goes to show you that you can actually consume a cyanide compound without harm, to a point, although please don't actually try consuming the pure chemical.

I used to work with hydrogen cyanide in a lab.  Before working with it, the client sent out a safety officer to determine who could smell it at low concentration.  He mixed up three beakers at below 1 ppm and two with distilled water.  Then he had each lab worker sniff them (you lift the cover, waft a bit towards your face, and sniff).  You had to correctly identify which had cyanide and which did not.  I can, but some people cannot smell it.  One lab person could not and was excluded from working on that project.  By the way, acidifying sodium cyanide is how prisoners were executed in the gas chamber.  I would not recommend trying anything he is doing.

I think the "smells like almonds" aspect comes from the fact that it used to be something you'd more commonly encounter. Bitter almonds are literally just almonds that are bitter. It's a recessive genetic trait that causes concentration of amygdalin in the almonds, so until it was cultivated to remove that trait, some almonds would just be bitter.

Saying cyanide smells like almonds is about like saying sulfur smells like rotten eggs (rotten eggs put off hydrogen sulfide) or that alcohol smells like vodka. It's associating the chemical smell with something you might have smelled it from.

I would agree, though, it's not useful anymore. I think the only reason it persists is that most people don't sniff cyanide either.

You can bring out the aroma of almonds by toasting them.  Also, when doctors say the cyanide smells almonds, it’s been metabolized by the body, not just crushed up in a beaker. That might create a smell.  Maybe it’s like how sometimes you can actually smell a sicky, sweet smell from a patient’s tissue or blood, (I can’t remember which), during an autopsy when the patient had been drinking.  The medical examiner that I worked for told me that some say they could smell the faint bitter smell of almonds with cyanide poisonings, but I didn’t smell anything different when we were doing the autopsy of a cyanide poisoning during the case of cyanide-laced Sudafed in Washington state in the early 1990s. I worked with a lot of pathologists in my career and this doctor was one of the smartest I had ever met. He was the doctor that started figuring the whole thing out. It turned out that some creep wanted to kill his wife for the life insurance, so he laced several packages of Sudafed and planted them around various stores to make it look random. His wife actually survived her poisoning, but other random victims did not.  If you revisit the almond smell issue, toast them in a skillet on the stove  or on a cookie sheet in the oven. You’ll smell them.
