Also, it's maybe a bit late now, but there are other sources of bitter almonds (sort of): Peaches are closely related to almonds, and their seeds have a closer composition to bitter almonds than sweet almonds, at least in terms of emulsin, amygdalin, and prunasin, (emulsin being the enzyme, and prunasin being another cyanogenic compound). If you let the pits dry overnight and whack them with a hammer, it's not too hard to get the seeds out.

As for why the knowledge that cyanide smells like bitter almonds is so widespread, they used to be used in cooking a lot more than they are now. They've pretty much always been cheaper than sweet almonds, and cooking evaporates the hydrogen cyanide off as it forms, so they're actually safe to cook with, especially since they have such a strong flavor, which means you can use a lot less to get almond flavor in your food, which means less cyanide to begin with. These days, though, they're harder to get than sweet almonds, since they're so poisonous raw and look similar to the safer sweet almonds. That's why you're a lot more likely to see someone use the smell to conclude someone was poisoned with cyanide in older (usually black and white) movies, and sometimes in movies set in the past.

I worked with KCN graduate school quite a bit.  Everyone was required to smell a bottle of the salt to know what to expect when joining the lab. I smelled the solid KCN to me it smelled like phenol and made me dizzy. (I never smelled the liquid HCN I synthesized from it.)  The post-doc in the lab said he got a very strong almond smell from it, very much like a bottle of benzaldehyde.  He could tell if I had weighed out some KCN in the room long before he entered.  Of all the people in the lab, he was the only one that smelled almonds, most got nothing or the chemical smell you describe.  We didn't have a fancy HCN meter, so I have no idea of the concentration.

The whole "cyanide smells like almonds" thing is one of those things that gets repeated and repeated so much that it gets distorted from the origin (like the well known "fact" that Einstein actually failed a bunch of math classes, which the records at colleges he attended refuted.)
The origin is that supposedly, cyanide smells somewhat like BITTER almonds, which is not analogous to the almonds we're used to. As most people aren't exposed to bitter almonds, they would have no frame of reference for their smell, and therefore couldn't correlate it to the supposed cyanide.

During my chemistry undergrad days I had been working with cyanide without even knowing it at first. We had to do the Lassigne test for determining nitrogen and carbon content in organic materials. The procedure involved heating a vial of the organic material with pure sodium and chucking the whole vial in a crucible full of cold water. The glass cracked and then we used to grind up the sodium + organic sample in the crucible and filter it. Depending on the carbon, halide, sulfur or nitrogen content we would get salts like sodium carbonate/halide/sulfate and of course, *sodium cyanide*. We worked without gloves.

Sodium thiosulphate is used as antidote for cyanide poisoning as well as fix for photographic film).The only reason I can think of this mixup is that noone have actually dared smelling HCN like this in a safe way and then instead wrongly have assumed that since bitter almonds contain it cyanide would smell like bitter almonds and that assumption have then stuck even it is the benzaldehyde and not the cyanide that gives this smell. I have a bitter almond tree growing by my house, so I've eaten them often. They are very, very bitter, and do have a sort of chemical taste, almost like strong bleach.

Bitter almonds and/or apricot kernels (which are very similar and close relatives) are used to make cookies here in Italy, usually "cut" with lots of sweet almonds (like 4 bitter, 100g sweet) or in very small quantities; in this way, i.e. at higher dilution, they really give cakes that "marzipan/benzaldehyde" smell. This is not unusual, skatole for instance smells like jasmine when very dilute, and litterally like shit when more concentrated. Amaretto liqueur is made out of bitter almonds, while amaretto cookies are basically just meringues with powdered apricot kernels!

Maybe you are just not very sensitive to this particular smell: I can easily detect it when I trim my cherry laurel hedge (also a close relative of almonds) and when I prepare cassava. The latter is interesting, because while the other three plants probably all contain amygdalin, being relatives in the genus Prunus , cassava does not: it's got two different cyanogenic glycosides that should not give off benzaldehyde. So... I suppose to me cyanide and benzaldehyde do smell very similar: they indeed both smell like bitter almonds, which contain both :)

Bitter almonds would taste like shit by themselves but when you make almond paste (not marzipan, this one is like 70% almonds and 30% sugar) you add in a small amount of bitter almonds and the taste is just heavenly. I don't know the exact ratio though, I suppose there is a threshold after which the taste goes to shit immediately. Once we ate around 50 grams (each) of such almond paste with a friend, a couple hours have passed and we both had some nasty but faint headache. We're alive though. Apricot kernels though contain a lot of cyanide and around 20 of them are supposed to be enough to cause serious poisoning. The smell is the same but far stronger with them (kinda weird to have something other than bitter almonds smell more like bitter almonds than the actual thing). The smell is mostly detectable while you are chewing them though.

Take the mug out and leave the almonds inside the mug with water for about 5-10 minutes. Take a spoon if the waters still hot and see if the almonds skin comes off. Now you can easily peel the almond skin off the almonds and just eat them skinless. Enjoy!

Cyanide is definitely interesting, and, as many know, also quite deadly. It's Halloween right now, as of this posting at least, so here's a morbid fact.

The main gas used in the old-school gas chambers in the US for capital punishment was Hydrogen Cyanide gas. To umm... "unalive" a person, they'd use Potassium Cyanide pellets and dump it into a bucket of sulfuric acid. This would cause HCN to be released and the person would breathe in the toxic fumes. It wasn't pretty.



If you go into the chemistry of cyanide, it is pretty interesting in its own right, beyond the morbidness of its use. What's also cool is that there are several different ways to detect cyanide. One includes the detector shown in the video, but there's also some cool chemistry that can be done. You can use ion chromatography to detect it and more research shows that there's even a method used to test environmental samples for cyanide. These detection methods are set forth by the US Environmental Protection Agency. If you look up EPA 335.4, you find a way to detect cyanide via spectroscopy. You use a reagent that has a mixture of Pyridine (Has one heck of nasty, fishy smell), Barbituric Acid, and HCL; a reagent that's a phosphate composition to maintain a buffer; and you use Chloramine-T as the final reagent. In the proper proportions, this mixture turns a nice color in the presence of cyanide, having a detectable range of 5 to 500 ug/L.

You also have various organic compounds with CN. Those cyanoacrylates are some stinky things.

I think the misconception about the smell of cyanide comes from ancient times when the only source was toxic plants. Producing and concentrating the cyanide contaminated with benzaldehyde would probably give the poison the classic "almond" smell we know. I'm not surprised it smells like pool chlorine, the structure of cyanide and hypochlorite have similarities.

You could use your cyanide to extract metals from ore or make gold plating.

The reason you found them in the medicine corner is about amygdaline, which is a natural component of bitter almond. this consists of a cyanine group -CN linked to a benzaldehyde part and 2 sugar molecules all in 1 molecule.

The claim is that the cyanide part is released only in the neighbourhood of cancer cells since they seem to have enzymes that can split this amygdaline molecule into its components cyanide, benzaldehyde and the sugar molecules. The cyanide does its destructive acts on the cancer cells and dies of...

That is the idea. ontop of that they are far cheaper that the big fpharma chemotherapies.. so these bitter almonds are pretty popular to many people. Including my self.

Now as a chemist myself I have seen many pro's and con's about these claimes... but yeah the price of bitter almonds is worth trying and as long as ne doesnt take too much it doesnt hurt any one. and if it indeed works against all kinds of cancer... why not ???

Some people (about half the population) just can't smell it, as you pointed out. It's a genetic thing. I have taken a whiff and it definitely smells like almonds, mixed with that strong burning smell of chlorine. I guess it is not that big of a deal in the grand scheme of survival, so evolution only "equpped" some of us to act as detectors :D
Also, it is not poisonous per se, it binds to your blood oxygen carriers (red blood cells?) PERMANENTLY and if you take enough in, your blood just can't supply enough oxygen to your body and you choke to death. Damage is reversible as those blood cells are constantly replenished by your body so the bad ones will be taken out of comission, but if you breathe in a big enough dose, there is no turning back and I don't think there is anything a doctor can do to save you (beside changing ALL of your blood, somehow instantly), even if he is right next to you when it happens. That's why it is considered extremely dangerous. Even poisons have antidotes and most of them take a while to kick in, which gives you time to react and save yourself, but cyanide is just plain lethal to anything that breathes like we do.

Based on some quick research, some various things you could use sodium cyanide for:
- Extracting gold from ore using the cyanide process (if you can get gold ore)
- As a chemical feedstock for cyanuric chloride, which can then be used to make atrazine, a herbcide
- Making things with nitriles, including methyl cyanoacrylate, used in superglues, and nitrile rubber, which the gloves you wear are probably made of
- Making benzyl cyanide, which is used in a variety of medications, including antiarrhythmics like disopyramide, antidepressants like venlafaxine, antihistamines like chlorphenamine, hypnotics like phenobarbital, and stimulants like methylphenidate. Honestly, this one could be interesting as a "can you believe we can get useful medicines that save lives out of something so deadly?"
Honestly, I'd find any of them interesting, though I guess I'd find the benzyl cyanide based medicines and the nitrile based superglue the most interesting.

I enjoy tasting the seeds from Apricots and other such fruits [on occasion]. (There's a seed that looks like a tiny almond in that pit!)  They are often bitter, yet fruity. They also seem to cause a tongue numbness. Make sure to look up toxicity information.

As far as I know, it's more like almond smells like cyanide. Because it has cyanide in it, albeit at really low concentrations ( around 25 mg of cyanide per kg of almonds). Most prunes (apricots, peaches, almonds) have cyanide in their seeds, to deter animals that crush their seeds while eating them. And the part of the almond we eat is the seed, so it has low levels of cyanide in it. But it's almost impossible to eat enough almonds to consume dangerous levels of cyanide. An average human needs to eat around 4-5 kilos of almonds to get cyanide poisoning, which is kind of a challenge.
The real exciting part is though, how did we domesticate almonds? Because wild almonds, also called bitter almonds have really high levels of cyanide in them. Eating as much as a handful of them could cause serious problems. But maybe 1 out of 1000 wild almonds have a genetic mutation that makes them safe to eat, with low concentrations. So our ancestors must've somehow singled out those trees and breed them, cultivating the almonds we eat today. Maybe they observed birds and other animals to determine the safe trees, but still, it's a huge risk, I personally wouldn't have taken it. I'm glad they did though, almonds are delicious and awesome!

I work in a lab, that analyses samples from a rectisol plant. The rectisol process uses methanol to clean sythesis gas from hydrogen sulfide, carbon dioxide and hydrogen cyanide, as well as some other stuff. I did an analysis of a sample, that contained lots of cyanide, but i didn't really think about that. I dumped the sample into the sink and smelled it right in that moment. "This has to be the bitter almond scent, everyone talks about" i thought by myself. Luckily it wasn't that high of a concentration and didn't have any issues 😅
At least, i now know, what cyanide smells like and i would never have associated it with almonds myself.
Also you stated, that the immediate death concentration is quite high... its not! 270 ppm is nothing. Thats 270 ml in a m3 of air. Imagine a plant, that produces 100 tonnes a day.

Old chemist here.  People's ability to smell cyanide is quite variable.  To me, cyanide (wafted from an open jar of NaCN in a humid environment) does indeed smell like almonds (or, perhaps, almonds smell like cyanide to me).  There are also a variety of chemicals (H2S, Me3P and tBuNC for example) that are very toxic, have very strong odors at low concentrations and exhibit what is known as olfactory fatigue (loss of smell) at higher (lethal) concentrations.  If you ever work with these materials and can't smell them, be very concerned.

When I was in high school, we had to do an insect collection for biology, so we made kill jars using cyanide. We basically wrapped duct tape around a jar to prevent shattering, and our teacher dumped in a spoonful of potassium cyanide in, which we topped with half an inch of plaster of paris. We poked little holes in the plaster to allow for better permeability.

We'd catch an insect and drop it in the kill jar and it would be dead within a minute or two.

When I'd open the jar, I'd catch little whiffs of marzipan -- a kind of nutty, sweet, almond-y scent. I had never heard the "bitter almond" association until I watched some Agatha Christie thing years later, but I was all "Aha!"

When I was a child we used to eat apricot kernels, which also contain cyanide. It wasn't just me, other children used to do it as well. I heard that they contain cyanide some time ago but only recently found out that people have died from eating them. They sell apricot kernels as alternative medicine remedy as well, found out about it from a Myles Power video. I'm guessing we got away with it simply because we would spit out the more bitter ones. Fancy safety system, I know.

Anyways, I find it interesting that cyanide has such a scary reputation when it's something that can be found in quite a few foods and, as far as I know, it is produced inside the human body in small quantities. People cook cassava on a daily basis, to release the cyanide, and I bet they don't use any protective gear. On the other hand, we had some major protests here in Romania against gold mining and people were talking about the use of cyanide like some mythical creature. Not that I disagreed much with the protests, but I do like looking at things somewhat more rationally.

Cyanide exists naturally in various foods - that is why cyanide "smells like almonds" - almonds contain cyanide. Almonds smell like cyanide, not the other-way around. Also the ability to smell cyanide is genetic - not all people actually smell cyanide.
Your body is able to handle some cyanide with no issue at all - it cccours naturally in various foods. Cyanide does not bio accumulate over time. You can take a pill with deathly does, split it into 30 pieces and eat it over a months time and your body will not have any problem with it (except when the pill was overkill by 30 and/or you have a serouis medical condition). Your body can detox at a rate of 0,1 mg per kg per hour according to wikipedia - that is insanely fast for such a toxin.

Bitter almonds are a variety of regular, sweet almonds. Bitter almonds contain traces of prussic acid—also known as hydrocyanic acid—in its raw state.
As few as seven to 10 unprocessed bitter almonds can kill a child, and roughly a dozen to 70 nuts can kill a 150-pound adult. The exact number depends on the size of the nuts.
Bitter almonds lose their toxicity when cooked; nonetheless, the sale of the unrefined nuts is prohibited in the U.S.

Your initial premise shows a lack of understanding of evolution (or you've just ignored it).  We've evolved to be disgusted by certain smells (rotting flesh, sewage, spoiled foods) because our ancestors who weren't revolted by the smell tended to die from infections without reproducing.  That's simple (and simplistic) natural selection.  So the lack of a natural revulsion to the smell of hydrogen cyanide is probably because there are so few natural sources of the gas that it's never really placed evolutionary pressure on us, or when it's been present it's been accompanied by something we do know and are repulsed by, like hydrogen sulfide.

Note that smells aren't inherent in chemicals, they're created in our brains/olfactory system. Evolution has made us experience putrescene and cadavrescene as extremely bad smells because it was evolutionarily advantageous to do so. Obviously, as you demonstrate, cyanide has been flagged as "really bad" by evolution, by connecting it to a bitter taste. A chemical that we've never had significant evolutionary interactions with, would not necessarily have it's own warnings attached to it.

Colors, even though we in some sense "create" them in our brains, seem to have a much clearer 1 to 1 mapping between experience and physical reality.

With people that bakes mandelkubb it is stated it has a rather distinct smell when in the oven and freshly out of it (I dislike almond in all forms, so I've never baked it), so it is on the post-heating side.

Since we have both types of almond in our lives we refer to them as "bittermandel" (bitter almond) and "sötmandel" (sweet almond), but if only "almond" is being used then it is assumed "sweet or both, unless earlier specified - but err on the side of sweet if for food, or bitter if for toxins".

Had always wondered about that.  I used to work in a hospital, and I often shared a cafeteria table with the pathology guys.  A fairly frequent topic of conversation among them was whether they thought each other would actually be able to notice the real cause of death if they were assigned the task of autopsying a patient who had died of poisoning.  The conversation was mostly about ragging on each other’s skills as pathologists, but it made me wonder.  I’d heard that a large number of people can’t detect the smell of cyanide, and if such a large number of people can’t smell it, I had wondered how many murders by poison might be being labelled incorrectly as natural causes deaths.

You know, I can't really smell almonds either.  And since I've grown lactose intolerant as I've gotten older, I've had to make the switch to almond milk.  And I've been asked a few times if I can taste the almonds, and the answer is no.  I suspect that's because the major component of taste is actually smell... and if you can't smell it, you can only taste it faintly at best.  So for me, almond milk basically tastes like low fat or skim milk.  It has a very faint (almost imperceptible) nutty after taste but it you use it on something like cereal that has nuts in it...  you can't discern if its the cereal or the almond milk.

So, at one of my jobs, I did a short stint in an electroplating house and was trained up to run the plating line. One of the tanks in there was Potassium Cyanide. It's used as an electrolyte for copper (specifically, "cyanide copper", you can electroplate copper also in s sulphuric electrolyte, I can't remember what the difference is but it has something to do with the metal's passifying). I was given the same warning about smelling almonds. It's also used as the electrolyte for gold plating.

The potassium cyanide tank was high concentration and was an almost syrup. To rinse that off you had to dip the load in the drag out tank (initially water, but slowly would become more and more concentrated with use) and then the sulphuric acid drag out, then mild sulphuric acid tank (+/-30%), back through the sulphuric drag out and then on to the next process. When dipping the load into both the sulphuric drag out/water rinse, and the mild sulphuric tank you could see white plumes of hydrogen cyanide gas forming in the tank. If you skipped any of the tanks in the process or the objects had voids that held the potassium cyanide, the plumes were orders of magnitude larger (watched some imbecile skip two tanks and had to evacuated everyone from the shed).

Thing is, I never smelt almonds and these were 6KLtr tanks. I saw considerable plumes generated and never smelt anything. Which made me wonder just as @Nile Red here, if it were true and what I should be looking for in case of a mishap. My theory was I could pretty much kiss my ass goodbye if there was an undetected event, because given the lack of odour for seemingly significant plumes of gas, that there would be little chance of smelling it over the other fumes in the shed, if you even could, by the time the concentration was high enough to kill you.

Perhaps by the time it smells like almonds, your goose is already cooked?

As far as using the cyanide for other projects, it's also used for reactivating passivized metals for plating (might be handy for other things?). E.g. if something is nickel plated and left to stand in the air for too long, it will passivate and the chrome plate won't stick to it. A 10 second blat through the cyanide tank with the object as the cathode, will reactivate the nickel plating and the chrome plate will then stick to it.

In the event of Cyanide poisoning, your only chance is Amyl Nitrite, which will buy you enough time for the ambulance ride, after that you're in the hands of the nurse's.

Story time: I had to run an experiment in a lab, so I turned on the power switch for the bench. University was too cheap to put in a fume hood so someone had built a plating line in the open area. 1) they had decided to leave everything on and control it by the same power switch and 2) they had spilled the gold cyanide solution on the hot plate and not cleaned it up. After 10 mins in the lab, I turned to my partner and asked him if he smelled anything. He said no, so we went on about our work and I shortly said that I still smell something like... Almonds. As soon as I said the word, I panicked and turned around to see the spilled solution on the hotplate bubbling away. We ran off and had symptoms for weeks

Just to do due diligence, I'd be curious if the plastic box and meter smelled like anything. It could just be that you're smelling the plastic (and rubber?) of other things in the box (or maybe a mixture). Smelling a control would let you know if the "chemical" smell even has to do with the almonds/cyanide.
If you did smell something, you may need a different setup for the experiment.
You could also try letting it build up, vent out the box, then smell -- just in case the smell is due to some mixing/reactions of the plastic/rubber of the meter, and not the cyanide directly. Just trying to cover all bases..

You added sulfuric acid. This combined in sodium cyanide produces largely ammonium sulfate, aka fertilizer, and.... sodium chloride/chlorine gas. Both deadly in their own rights, but... once you add another chemical to a mixture, it is no longer the same mixture. For the almond-esque scent, you need to go with potassium based cyanide, rather than sodium, and particularly it becomes noticeable when cooked/heated. Also... bitter almonds smell like cyanide, not the other way around, and it's because they CONTAIN cyanide naturally.

Well, I know that I can smell HCN: 40 years ago, on vocational training, my class had to deal with the qualitative inorganic analysis. One aspect there was to "mask" Cadmium ions, so they won't interfere with the detection of other heavy metal ions. For this reason, a small amount of potassium cyanide, was added to the sample containing several heavy metals. This solution had to be boiled then, in the hood of course. One "expert" did this step on his workbench outside the hood and a faint scent of HCN filled the lab. That was also detected by our chemistry teacher/supervisor and the guy was called immediately  in the supervisor's office for a "briefing". My next encounter with HCN was a year later, while a laboratory assistent in my neighbourhood carried out a whole series of experiments for the synthesis of Mandelic Acid, starting from from benzaldehyde, 30% NaCN-solution und H2SO4. The HCN was released in situ and added onto the aldehyde to form the cyanhydrine, which was hydrolysed in the next step. Here, one or two times, traces of HCN managed to escape from the vessel. I always associate the smell of almonds with benzaldehyde, while HCN resembles me more to the smell of Acetonitrile.

The reason it smells like pool chemicals is because the chlorine breaks down amides, and some of the breakdown products will be very short carbon links and often bare amide groups where the CN is split off all the rest, and then reacts with water to form the HCN. Also a lot of pool chemicals have sodium cyanide added to them to improve the disinfection ability, and it is also going to be present in the acid as a contaminant.

They also say the same about benzaldehyde, a molecule often organically associated with the nitriloside moiety, as in Laevo-mandelonitrile-Beta D-glucoside as found in bitter almonds and apricot pits.

Interestingly, Hydrogen cyanide, HCN, is in fact a vitamin, as proven by Mendel and Blood in 1910, by studying the enzyme papain. The potency of papain was relatively inactive in the absence of HCN. It is a co-enzyme, hence a water soluble B vitamin. Furthermore it is incorporated in pro-vitamin B12 or cyanocobalamin. Additionally, the red blood cells possess enzyme for extracting HCN from thiocyanate. The body does not preserve such mechanisms unless it is useful. HCN is highly labile and facilitates the hydrolase cycling. Sumner and Somer listed several inhibited serine enzymes reactivated by HCN.

The rationale of laetrile as a selective poison to cancer cells was misinformed. Rather the HCN reactivates the enzymes that will digest cancer cells and their primary enzyme inhibitor or serpin hCG. hCG also serves as a cell wall component in cancer cells, which confers a highly electrochemical negative charge, as do the white blood cells. Hence they are mutually repelled.

I guess the reason why people say cyanide smells like almonds is because at some point, the original person or people that found cyanide was in bitter almonds had smelled the benzaldehyde and thought that it was what cyanide smells like. Then as it was passed along, the "bitter" part of the information could have been lost in translation, which lead to the cyanide smells like almonds saying. The misleading nature of it could cause people to freak out whenever they smell the nice almond smell and that's bad news.

well Cyanide is really great to test SN2 reactions (SN1 reactions work too and often enough you can't tell the difference anyway, but Cyanide usually works with SN2. Aka backside attack) one of the coolest things I've seen is the so called finkelstein reaction. You take an Alkylchloride and react it with potassium iodide and either sodium or potassium cyanide in acetone.
It is a really nice demonstration of equilibriums. You know, Alkylchlorines can react with iodides and form the metal chloride and the alkyliodide, however as the Iodide is WAY more reactive it will immediately turn back. BUt potassium iodide is somewhat soluble in Acetone while potassium chloride is not at all soluble meaning it crashes out. The Cyanide is somewhat soluble too and well the alkyliodide is highly reactive, while the forming nitrile is kind of a dead end. (carbon-carbon bond. that's not gonna break for something primitive like a substitution So the reaction will go to completion)

Your almonds didn't smell like anything because you used sweet almonds ( Prunus dulcis ). If you had gotten ahold of bitter almonds ( P. dulcis var. amara ) you would have smelled the distinctive odor of (surprise!) oil of bitter almonds. To me, at least, it smells like cherries. Sweet almonds contain a very small amount of hydrogen cyanide. Bitter almonds contain about 40 times more more. The cyanide is produced by the hydrolysis of amygdalin. This trait is the result of a single recessive gene.

17:50 - sorry, but as a chemist I have to strongly disagree. We never tell people "if you all smell almonds, please leave the lab". We always tell people, that some people can't smell certain harmful chemicals (it's not only HCN) and hence it's extremely important that you report any weird smells to the teaching assistant. Also: It's hammered into the brains of chemistry students to never mix cyanides with acids, work in a fume hood, and to always dispose of them in a basic solution. Accidents with cyanides basically never happen - quite the opposite to H2S, which is a regular problem in basic lab courses.

There are some compounds that pharmacologically have different effects (or in this case smells) depending on the dosage; at low concentrations you could smell one thing but at high concentrations you could smell something totally different. Turns out, out of the 33 chemists in the place, only 2 could smell it, me included...
